body.p: Remarks on the Christian duty of putting an and to slavery by Joseph John Gurney Sanganton that for That it is our bounden duty as Christians to labour in the cause of the abolition of slavery, is a proposition so reasonable & obvious, that one might have supposed, no one could have doubted its it. Yet such is the perversion of heart & intellect to which were all be mankind are liable, that sane persons have contrived to persuade thamselves, that their Christion duty, in reference to this subject, lies absolute inaction. In the first place, they urge as a plea for their non-interference, the curse promounced by Noah on Canaan "Cursed be Canaan", said the offended Patriarch? a servant of servants shall he be to his brethren? Gen. IX. 20 Since the person by whom Noah had been offended was not Canaan, but his father Ham, its it is taken for granted by these objectors that "Canaan", is here put for "Ham". And since Ham, through his eldest son Mizraim, was the Progenitor of the Africans, it is concluded they conclude by them, first That the prophecy is accomplished in the slavery of the Negroes, & secondly, that therefore in laboring for the emancipation of the Negroes, we labor against the declared decree of the Lord of all the earth. Now supposing this interpretation application of the prophecy to be correct the African race to be the true one, what can be more absurd than such a practical inference? The duration of Canaanâ€™s servitude, is a subject on which does it contain the prophecy says nothing; much less is there the slightest intimation, that their cruel bondage was to have no end. Who then shall say, that the time is not come for its the of African slavery extermination. O who can deem it unreasonable to suppose that in effecting this object, God may be pleased to make use of human instrumentality. But I can by no means assent to such an interpretation of the prophetic record; & which I believe received its accomplished accomplishment when the Canaanites who were left in the land of Palestine, became hewers of wood & drawers of water -- to the degraded performers of the most laborious offices -- to their Israelitish Conquerers[?], who were [?] descended from Shem. It is highly probable ^also, that many of these enslaved persons[?] ^Canaanites were also exported from Tyre & Sidon, & became slaves to the European nations, the descendants of Japheth. And he said, Blessed be the Lord God of Shem, & Cannan shall be his servant. God shall Canaan shall be enlarge Japheth & Canaan ...... & Canaan his servant. v. 25. 26 Thus utterly vain, is the first plea of our objectors; but here we come in contact with a lewd plea -- "The Israelites" The Israelites held their fellow men in slavery a practice in which they acted under the authority of their inspired Legislator." It is certainly true that the ancient people of God were permitted by their law, to make slaves both of the Canaanites who were left in the land, & of their captives taken in war, & equally so, that the bondage thus imposed contrived during life. "Both thy bondmen & bondmaid which then shalt have, shall be of the heather that are round about you, which they begat in your land, & they shall be you possession. And ye shall take them as an inheritance for your children after you, to inherit them for Levit XXV 44. 45.
